not wearing glasses this time around because I'm in a good mood and wanna be earnest.

this year and even the past month have been really fucking awful for me in a lot of different ways, but for some reason today I was in a good mood. Maybe it was the fact that "Smash Mouth - All-Star" was playing in my head, or maybe it was me finally accepting that I can, and should put the neuroses and misfortune of this past year behind me and live the life I truly want in 2023, maybe it was just pleasantly sunny.

Anyway, here's to a happy new year for me, and all of you too, even my fellow tripfags, strange bedfellows though they are.
A year where we can put the hardships of this last one behind us, and move forward in all our best qualities, values, and pursuits, and none of our worst flaws, anxieties, and vices.

And to those who aren't even sure what their best qualities, values, or pursuits are, who don't know who they wanna be, what they wanna do, or whether they even deserve to try, (and believe me, I've been there this year)
here's me praying to whoever's listening that the coming 12 months are packed sunday to saturday with growth and discovering the best version of yourself you can be, and that I'm able to have that too.

posts.com:
>>17425221
1: If you haven't already, get a vintage bottle of Salvador Dali Pour Homme. Easy to find on eBay, worst case scenario grab a sealed splash bottle and decant into an atomizer. The whole honey tobacco profile for Mugler Pure Havanne/Naxos/18.21 Man Made etc is close to a direct rip from this fragrance. You need the vintage though, which is still cheap. It's also very wearable today, especially since Sauvage Elixir and Beau Du Jour are mainstream.

If you have that go to these next:
Vintage Caron Pour un Homme. Skanky as shit, best kept secret if you like Kouros and Antaeus style frags.
Dior Jules
Dior Eau Sauvage. Vintage 1oz bottles are normally available on eBay.
Vermeil Pour Homme
Maxim's Pour Homme. Another underated classic animalic. Part of me is always greedy and doesn't want to recommend this but it's so good that I have to. Floral,leather, oakmoss, animalic.
Alain Delon Iquitos. The most beautiful fragrance for men I've ever smelled, and it's skanky as hell. Smells hot, tropical, sensual. There's cool history here with Dior rejecting the fragrance and then regretting it, and the frag was discontinued due to ingredient availability rather than reformulate. Get a mini on eBay at least, everyone should smell this one.

I can't stand florals in most men's frags today, the fact that frags like Lyric for Men, Toy Boy and Declaration Soir get pushed as good florals make me shake my head. Florals in the late 70s to early 90s were more common and still MANLY.

Paco Rabanne Tenerre . Similar spirit to Iquitos, different execution. Civet and honey, musk, moss, patchouli and leather with a bouquet on the side. Has a strange dusty vibe which is somehow pleasant.

Azarro Acteur. Leather bomb with a huge blood red rose note, voluptuous and sensual. Great use of nutmeg as well. Somewhat modern smelling too, could be released today as niche and people would go ape shit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17425368
2: Paloma Picasso Minotaure. Beautiful fragrance, works flawlessly today. Orange musky creamsickle. Works so well that Almariac decided to be a giant bitch and release the exact same fragrance again and call it Wake Up World but charge niche price. I'm not joking, it's the same fragrance, you can read about it on Fragrantica. save your money, buy a vintage bottle on eBay of the first formulation. Runs 50-70, juice smells fine as long as the box is sealed and unused.

Carlo Corinto for men. Soapy, herbal green leather Fougere with a strong and anachronistic raspberry note. I think Tom Ford got the idea for Tuscan Leather here.

Aramis Havana. Still my favorite tobacco fragrance. Orange,allspice, bay leaf, tobacco, rum and leather. This fragrance just feels passionate and alive. The rerelease isn't bad, but if you want the real deal look for the original blue bottles.

Cappucci Pour Homme. A rougher, more herbal and spicy Acqua Di Parma Colonia


Versace L'homme. Saving the best for last. Pure Italian, perfect mix of class and sleaze. Citrus, musk, leather. Not complicated but executed immaculately, back when Versace was run by the real talent. Easy to find the vintage on eBay, font style is different on the original bottles. Price is low but will skyrocket as supply dwindles.


That's it for now. I've tried to stick with ones that are readily available on eBay for less than $100, Iquitos is the exception but you can still get a mini which will last for years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17425468
I'm actually going through a major Zino phase right now. I bought a small bottle of the vintage last year because of all the Beau de Jour comparisons. I liked it but was also kind of disappointed because I found the opening sour and astringent, and it didn't smell that close to Beau de Jour. And because the bottle I got was so small I was reluctant to wear it much.

Then a few weeks ago I finally bought a bottle of current Zino (along with the deodorant) because it's dirt cheap and I wanted to see how it compared to the vintage. Something clicked when I sprayed it for the first time, and I completely fell in love. It's all I've wanted to wear recently, and I like it even more than Beau de Jour now (I guess this is growing up?). Also the current and vintage are about 90% identical (vintage is a bit stronger, but you can compensate by spraying more).

The opening can still be kind of challenging--intense mouth-watering bergamot and lavender, which can come across as pissy at times. But I think it's gorgeous. Then it dries down into some beautiful dusty patchouli and vanilla, with echoes of rose and geranium, the lavender still humming in the background.

So to answer your question, yes Zino is comfy.

I don't think it's that similar to Z-14. Z-14 is a light woody citrus + cinnamon to my nose, and Zino is darker and heavier (but not oppressively so). You should definitely blind buy Zino if you're at all interested. At this point I'm thinking it's the best value-for-money in all of men's perfumery

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17427665
such sound advice straight up. Glad to see it.

I'm hoping we've all moved past the 'trying to look like something we're not' phase of fashion, which is beginning to bore me. So often I tried out different styles, which was fun for a while, because I liked how it looked on other people. But a lot of the time I was really just trying to keep up with looking as cool as possible. Now it bores me. SO much of fashion bores me. I honestly don't even know what my style is really. I like the look of a lot of things on people. I definitely have a taste, but in terms of waking up and getting dressed every day, I stop trying to think so much about what I have to prove. Instead I start to understand what I actually reach for, what I feel confident in, what feels good on me.
I guess I'm just rambling cause I've been doing a closet clear out these past few days, very gradually. It's hard parting with clothes that you recognise are perfectly good pieces, even interesting or well made and that you would like to wear, but just know you never probably will... I think doing a proper closet cleanout will probably yield the most honest results more than any pinterest moodboard could, of what your 'style' is. It's good to get experimental and stuff, but be realistic about your life. What kind of energy do you really want to invest in what you wear? What reflects all of your other passions and interests? And also, be real, what colours actually look good on you, and what kind of suck? (for me, I've realised yellow is no good... Had to part with some really special t-shirts, but I'd never reach for them anyway).

I rejected this advice for the longest time, and I can empathise with the tentativeness at actually culling your things, but fuck it saves so much energy in the long run. Plus I made a shit tonne of money off doing market stalls, putting them in consignment, selling them in specialised boutiques, etc. There's always options.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17428170
anyway, I wanted to just add this note:
don't be afraid of having 'phases'. We are naturally always evolving and changing. Even if you find your style, within 10 years that will probably change. But that's OK. What reflects who you are now is worth investing in, and worth caring about, but don't take it too seriously, and remember that it's allowed to change.

And yeah, don't buy fast fashion. Don't be desperate to own every piece thats kinda cool or interesting. It's way worth waiting for the best thing to come to you, and for it to stay for a long time, not just for the moment you saw it and thought it was really cool and that everyone who would see you wear it would think you were really cool because it was the cool thing to wear. It'll almost always be a waste of money.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I took a picture but did not assume the position.

Color is weird because it's indoors at night.
IRL it looks a bit darker and less yellow, but I haven't seen them in sunlight yet.

My feet are a bit over 28cm by 11cm. I think that makes me like US11.25E (wide) on Brannock.
These are US11E on the Trubalance last which is the biggest/widest/comfiest last Alden has (but the heel is two sizes narrower)

The fit feels exceptional but I would not give final judgment before wearing them at least three times. I like that the toebox is not too tall, there is not a lot of excess height on the vamp. This is rare for my feet. I felt no heel slip at all despite being roomy in the front, also rare.
The last is chunky, it actually protrudes significantly in the big toe area for comfort, but the vamp stitching is a straight line from the laces which hides this fact very well.

The quality of the build feels ok but not special. I am surprised at how rigid the heel stiffener feels, there's no way this is not celastic. Stitching is just okay. It is fully lined. The suede feels ok but not as good as Charles F Stead suede that I also own.

The quality of the finishing is mediocre. The 'storm welt' is a little sloppy but nothing terrible and nothing that would be visible unless closely examined. Stitching is good all around. There was a bit of glue under one of the speedhooks and it has left a small black mark on the suede (visible in the photo on the right boot). I am not going to return them over this, it's high up and on the inside of the boot.

Overall, it's what I thought they would be. Overpriced but you pay for the unique styling. I like it and I hope they are comfy so I can wear them all the time.

posts.name: Anonymous

Spray it with suede waterproofing every few months
Saphir has suede renovateur in spray form too if needed

Normal horsehair brush gets rid of dust etc just fine

If it gets very dirty, use suede soap, let it dry and brush it.

Some of them work out too but im still a skinny dyel). To make friends with anyone else here seems like an insurmountable wall.
Yet i dont know how to talk to them without coming across as weird. I thought i could wait for a chance to say something during the semester if they were having a conversation about a topic i like but the chance never really came, and when it did i couldnt think of anything to say.
So ive probably already cemented myself as a shy autist in their minds, or at the very least weird.
I feel like i have more than enough to make friends here but i dont know how to take the first step.
When you made friends, did it just happen? Or did you have to work for it? Or a mix of both?
And where can i learn how to make friends?
I always hear "look for clubs on campus" but i genuinely think theres none here. The closest thing i can think of was my cal teacher holding after-class meetings in a nearby room for help with math homework. Which i didnt need because i already took a highschool class of cal 1 and 2 (it wasnt a college credit type thing but it helped me immensely this past semester and will help this next semester).
But it felt awkward getting my tests and quizzes back and seeing 95s-100s while everyone around me was lucky to get an 80. I saw the guy sitting in front of me trying to glance back at one of my test grades. Wonder what he thinks of me.
I feel terrible for never offering help. I think they all passed, the 11 other people left in the class.

>>17422844
>How often do you change your razor?
>Dont tell me you fall for the “every 5-7 shaves” jew
>I change my every 2 months

I use a Gillette Mach3. I usually get around 4 months' worth of daily shaves out of a cartridge before I start to get irritation. My beard is pretty heavy but I'm still young so my skin is soft and prone to irritation.
The trick is to rinse the blades off in alcohol before you put the razor away. Minerals in the water left on the blade form deposits on the cutting edges. Alcohol displaces the water so it's perfectly dry.

>>17423659
You're sadly getting left behind a bit. Current trends are showing that a simple necklace plus other simple accessories are rising up.

I do two rings (one per hand, non-married for now [popping the question in a few months, mostly likely]), one with a simple design one with a more complex statement-piece style design. I rotate between ring options from there.

For a bracelet, a simple thin metal cuff works, or beads. But only one beaded bracelet, since more looks a bit tacky and outdated. The goal is to find something that complements your watch on your other wrist: I do the cuff with my metal Orient and a black beaded bracelet for my Invicta Submariner homage. With a NATO strap on the Invicta, it's a solid look that I've gotten complements on.

Don't do the bracelet + watch thing imo, it's not great.

Top all of that off with a simple necklace (sterling silver if pale skin, gold if dark skin) worn under the shirt (so that the metal peeks out every so often rather than all the time), and you're pretty set.

Granted I live in Florida, so accessories have to do a lot of work during hot periods where layering is impossible. Either way, the key is to get simple pieces and not to overdo it. One statement piece is fine, more is pushing it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17426283
Don't. Those ones are not fit for purpose, if they are not pure essential oils or fragrance-grade synthetics you will probably get rashes. Finding the right natural materials is hit and miss, you need to find which ones are good quality, i.e. don't have bad after-smells. It's a good idea to make the aromatic base 80:20 naturals:synthetics (musks, aromachemicals like geraniol, coumarin, beta-ionkne, ethyl vanillin, etc.) for better longevity. Find some good essential oils get some spray bottles (glass, not plastic) and dilute the pure individual oils with ethanol to 10% using a precision, jeweler's scale, and spray them on your skin. If they smell good as the odor develops, you can use them in a fragrance. After that it's a tedious process of experimenting with different ratios. Study which notes are base, middle and top (based on relative longevity) and experiment. Use ethanol as a diluent, you want to aim for about 15% total concentration of the final product.
> What's you recipe
It's mine, you can't have it >:(.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17424186
27 y/o. From favorite to least favorite. Eau Extreme, although being the most expensive out of all, was a big disappointment personally, too flowery, very little sillage, when it does die down the tonka smells nice but it doesn’t last nearly as long as my other fragrances. Drakkar Noir is decent, but it really kind of just reminds me of shower gel on steroids. Dry down is a nice musk though. Dylan Blue I consider my “signature scent” I use regularly. First fragrance I bought and I like it because its musky but not aggressive, and is pleasantly sweet. Gotten many compliments on it. Fahrenheit blew my mind, and is hands down my favorite scent out of the four. Its musky and animalistic, but also refined. Massive longevity and sillage. Only reason I don’t wear it daily is because it’s so aggressive. I read a review of it, “sex in a bottle”, that perfectly describes it. Its intimidating and I’m afraid, very afraid.

based welding thread

I've been welding 3 or 4 years now, it's definitely not effay but it's good honest work for a decent pay - it makes university educated office bitches absolutely sperg out on 4chan for some reason. I think a lot of people end up working in rock-bottom sweatshops welding trailers for $18/hr alongside Pedro and Paco with no respirators and grow to despise it. It's a good career if you take care of your personal health and safety and follow some kind of upward career trajectory instead of killing yourself in some bottom-scraping hellhole. Invest in training and certifications, and focus on enhancing your skill set, and it can be pretty comfy.

Just started my apprenticeship with the UA pipefitters local up in leaf land, before that I was job-hopping for a few years in different fab shops - mostly metal core with some flux core and most recently spic-tier MIG hardwire work (was overpaid, took the money and ran). I have stories, man.

posts.com:
>>17427045
>Is welding a job that pays well enough

Pays enough. Good money means different things to different people but you won't be broke and you'll always have work. It's not rockstar money but it's a living for sure. If you make good career moves, get your red seal (or whatever your equivalent is), specialize in something, and gain a good reputation, you can make low six figures. But that takes years. The better you get the more money you can command, straight up. Nobody is gonna be asking you for references at interviews nor will they give a shit about gaps in your resume. They want to see how good you can weld and how certified you are. Certifications ie "tickets" are EVERYTHING. GET YOUR TICKETS. Get as many tickets as you can muster. Invest heavily in certification. I made 35k-ish my first year, 50-60k my second and third, will be 80k this year - now I am starting an apprenticeship with the pipefitters union, after that - I've heard a lot of stories of guys lining their pockets welding pipe, we shall have to see.

Realize that this board tends to attract the wealthy and 4chan in general attracts all kinds of IT-rich autists so again - good money means different things to different people. If you consider 80k a good income yeah go for it if you're hoping to command top 1% wealth there are better avenues like IT or business management.

>can be enjoyable
As you can see there are tons of people in this thread who did not enjoy welding, and several who did. If you can get the chance, take a short course or something and see if it's for you. I quite like it, and passion will take you everywhere. It's a craft known to burn people out so if you are young and eager you are like gold to employers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Long ass post but there's a clothing-related point.
For the winter I bought a merino wool thermal layer for my legs. I found a pair that were 100% merino for a good price. When I unwrapped them, they were literally SO stretchy that I had to re-check the label to make sure they had 0% synthetics. And theyre not itchy at all. After a couple months of wearing the same pair every work day, there's no sign of wear. This is proof that the idea that clothing like socks and underwear absolutely NEED synthetics for durability and stretch is complete BULLSHIT. You don't need to put plastic on your body.

Also, when I was looking for merino socks, I read info on a manufacturer's website that was very enlightening. Their socks were ~40% wool and then 10-20% each of various synthetics. They claimed that this was because the different synthetics all had different qualities that made the perfect sock. Yet It also said that, by US law, wool MUST be the largest single material to market it as wool clothing. So they basically admitted that they use a melange of 4 synthetics just to ensure that wool is still technically the plurality, so they can be legally labeled as merino socks. Another reason not to trust the narrative that synthetics are for performance and not cost-cutting.

You are close to realizing the scale of the operation of shifting accountability for petroleum waste and byproducts from corporations to consumers. Even smaller local companies are just unwitting dupes to facilitate the exchange. Plastic spits in the face of the biological/preternatural creature. "plastic is cheap" is STILL a marketing gimmick. Plastic is quite literally worthless, and, considering it's uniquity, you are being conned paying even a cent for anything made of it. Moreoever, the culture of plastic enabling cheap manufacture has even mutated classically designed garments such that, even when made of 100% natural local materials, they are shaped like something out of a chinese factory, designed by a brain fried homosexual or some borderline lardass woman.

Plastic is cheap enough to be tempting to consumers, and priced at all, to legally justify it's path down the hierarchy quickly, considering that it is already waste this process is outrageous. Soon enough, the end user has a whole house full of literal garbage refashioned into otherwise useless items. Eventually they have to throw their crap away or dispose of it by burning. So they pay twice, once for the inherently defective product, which is an explicitly fiscal exchange, and twice - this time, the cost isn't necessarily monetary - for the inevitable disposal of it. If they pay in money, they pay the municipal council or a contracted private company who have their money circulate back up to where the chain began via the same unwitting dupe nepotism.

You can look at it from so many angles. My favorite is the schizo interpretation, that 'they' who profit off of such an exchange are trying to destroy the world and the quality of the souls thereof. Even in that interpretation you can go for the bataillean view, that such waste is part of the vigor and violence of reality, or the mystical view, that it's a kind of tikkun olam/tempting hand of God.

Our relation to animals is more interesting-I mean to the animals we eat. We adore eating veal, lamb, beef, antelope, pheasant, or grouse, but we don't throw away their "leftovers."
We dress in leather and adorn ourselves with feathers. Like the Chinese, we devour duck without wasting a bit; we eat the whole pig, from head to tail; but we get under these animals' skins as well, in their plumage or in their hide.

Men in clothing live within the animals they devoured. And the same thing for plants. We eat rice, wheat, apples, the divine eggplant, the tender dandelion; but we also weave silk, linen, cotton; we live within the flora as much as we live within the fauna.
We are parasites; thus we clothe ourselves. Thus we live within tents of skins like the gods within their tabernacles. Look at him well-dressed and adorned, magnificent; he shows-he showed-the clean carcass of his host.

Of the soft parasite you can see only the clean-shaven face and the hands, sometimes with out their kid gloves. We parasite each other and live amidst parasites. Which is more or less a way of saying that they constitute our environment.
We live in that black box called the collective; we live by it, on it, and in it. It so happens that this collective was given the form of an animal: Leviathan. We are certainly within something bestial; in more distinguished terms, we are speaking of an organic model for the members of a society.
Our host? I don't know. But I do know that we are within. And that it is dark in there.

M. Serres - The Parasite

>>17427135
Have similar set up. Eyes are puffy, or baggy, resulting in a sort of sunken look. Its a circulation thing. The blood vessels around the eyes are the most delicate, any amount of fucking around will puff them up even more. Allergies also exacerbate the issue. Some bare minerals complexion rescue tinted SPF 30 works well, and helps with tone, too. But honestly the best thing is looking at your facial expressions, and understanding how to look good with your face as is. Op pic is a good example - dudes got naturally good jawline, and his eyes are flush, but that's also a practiced expression, and he's wearing makeup, and he probably does facial exercises. Check out gua sha -- with a little time and effort, your skin and the cartilaginous tissue around your cheekbones should be optimized a bit, which will also help address the eye thing. Each of these things are like 10%, but when you're looksmaxxing every little bit helps, and after the initial learning (which is trivial) it's just a regular thing and takes no extra time.

>>17423741
It's one of the best looking G-Shocks. The timers are amazing but I hate not having the current time in all modes. The buttons are also a bitch to press, some oldfags even boiled the resin to make the buttons easier to press. The dual illuminator looks fantastic and it's a shame they don't put that feature on newer G-Shocks. Without a dual illuminator you have no idea what the charge level or alarms are in the dark on models like the GW-M5610U or the GW-6900. It's a medium sized watch for a G-Shock so I wouldn't recommend it for small wrists. Not the most comfortable but wearable. It's has been discontinued for a while but there is plenty of stock left.

tldr: kinda outdated but some better features not present on modern G-shocks and looks great
7/10

If you want a small watch you can get an F91W. It's smaller than most mechanicals. For shock protection G-Shock has a floating design which makes the case bigger. The resin bezel also makes it more durable and larger. The models in the "man" series like Mudman and Frogman are designed to be used in environments where people are wearing gloves so the buttons are large and the bezel is bigger. A square G-Shock is about the size of a modern mechanical.

>>17425114
The nato does dress it down but you could even get the same watch without the flashy strap. Sometimes I feel it’s tacky and sometimes I feel like I miss it so I wear the bracelet seasonally.

eBay actually inspects their watches, Jomashop is known to be reliable, and Chrono24 I have never used but they hold the money you pay in escrow as a protection + it depends on the seller.

With all that said, this watch is too obscure to have much of a chance of many reps of it. Making a believable rep is a serious production so they generally only get their ROI if there will be many buyers think AP Royal oak or most stainless Rolex. You would be just fine, I had the same thoughts as you and paid retail at a shop for peace of mind since I was brand new and finally had enough money to buy my first “real watch”. My taste is very different now but I will keep this watch anyway because of the memories of it.

TLDR you should be fine. It also has a clear caseback for you to evaluate the finishing.

>>17426155
>>17426268
To expand on that shit, generally, watches are watches, but some of them can play specialized roles
- Dress watches are the only thing compatible with a tuxedo (assuming you're even gonna wear ANY watch with a tuxedo). They need to be classy and minimal with a leather strap, and above all, THIN
- Dive watches are defined by their higher water resistance compared to other shit and they usually have a rotating bezel with minute markers for tracking your oxygen
- Pilot watches used to have special anti-magnetic cases, luminous dials, and giant crowns so you could wind them with your gloves on. None of that is particularly relevant in modern airplanes though so you're more likely to see tachyometer shit or a rotating bezel with time zone markings
- Chrono watches are watches that are also stopwatches (chronometers). I don't know why it's a separate column there because there's a lot of overlap with pilot watches these days
- Field watches originate in the military, which is how men's wristwatches got popularized in the first place. I'm not as familiar with this kind but I've seen a lot of them that swap the hour and minute markings so you can use them to time the firing of an artillery barrage, which I'm sure everyone here does all the time

>easy access to last signal received time
>battery level display

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It'd be cool to have some feedback. Pic related is my poorfag collection. The casio I bought used and the seiko and citizen were gifts.

I read a lot of advice given online that you should avoid buying cheap watches and save up for the next tier of watches. This makes sense in some ways but it also really hammers home that these things are flashy consumerist fetishes, where there are tiers and boxes to be ticked. I like the idea that you get a watch simply because you like it, regardless of the price. many watches from the big brands are as ugly as sin to me. And just looking for whatever watch from them you find the least ugly and possesses the most "value" seems ridiculous.

However, on the flip side, part of the irrational romanticism of these things is that you can potentially have them for decades and pass them onto your children, which is more easily achieved with higher quality watches.

What are you all's thoughts? I'd like to get a watch to commemorate finishing grad school in year and change from now, and have my eye on a Citizen NB1060-12L, but I'm wondering if I'd be better off getting something "better" like a Sinn or Oris.

I'm also thinking of getting an Orient bambino but wondering if it'd be worth it

>>17427236
I've been interested in watches for about 15ish years. My collection goes from Casio to modern Jaeger-LeCoultre. I might have some helpful insight as I have bought (and sold) many foolish watches.
>I read a lot of advice given online that you should avoid buying cheap watches and save up for the next tier of watches.
Good advice generally speaking.
>it also really hammers home that these things are flashy consumerist fetishes, where there are tiers and boxes to be ticked
Sort of. As opposed to seeing them as boxes to tick, I see these "tiers" and "boxes" as helpful rules of thumb so that people who may not be very knowledgeable about watches don't get screwed by the many hucksters in the industry. There is certainly fetishism over Rolex and Patek but it seems to be cooling with the market.
>I like the idea that you get a watch simply because you like it
Great. You should do this within reason. People get in trouble because they impulse buy stuff, then years later they're back here posting about how they have 30 worthless microbrands and talking about how they wished they had just bought something better initially.
>many watches from the big brands are as ugly as sin to me.
Sure. Lots of big manufacturers are going through a bit of a design slump. Omega, TAG, Rolex, AP, Vacheron, even Cartier who is normally a design power house have all been somewhat boring recently.
>I'd like to get a watch to commemorate finishing grad school in year and change from now, and have my eye on a Citizen NB1060-12L, but I'm wondering if I'd be better off getting something "better" like a Sinn or Oris.
Sinn is a good brand. Oris is improving. If that's your price range, I'd go with a Sinn or Nomos if you're want serious horological chops with decoration and highly integrated vertical manufacturing. Nothing wrong with Casio, but I would treat myself on a grad watch because you will probably have it forever.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>17426380
That's all cool, but itchy is itchy bro. You can use the Ultra Purist argument, but if something is straight up uncomfortable even after many wears of breaking it in, then its likely overhyped (especially in the case of Pendleton) and a no go. There are tiers of cotton. I think you're mistaking cotton as being some structurally deficient material that is only used amongst mass producers of fast fashion clothing. Japanese clothing companies almost exclusively use cotton, often times resorting to higher quality cotton in order to make a superior flannel or pair of denim. For example, Iron Heart uses Aspero cotton for their flannels which supposedly is unable to be mass produced and is prized for its high strength, softness, fineness, and volume. Just because something is wool does not indeed make it a superior piece of clothing. Sure, it may breath really well and have a decent structural integrity, but if it doesn't meet the comfort criteria then I cannot imagine justifying paying some of the prices that are often charged for pieces of wool clothing.

TLDR:Business Trip with young Start Up

I went straight to working from home after College and never visited an office or anything close to that. Now I am planning my first business trip, where I join the CEO of an startup to meet real estate agents, low level government employees and other consultants in major cities across the US. I never seen anyone in the company wear a suit, but I only ever saw them through ZOOM in their house.

I already have blue and white dress shirts and relatively nice v-neck Pullovers, different Styles of Polo Shirts as well as light/dark brown and dark blue Chino Pants. Can I get by with that or do I need to add (or take away) some items? I don’t want to look or come across like pic rel, but still “follow the rules“.

Also which shoes would work? I only have new balance sneakers and some Lacoste Boat shoes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
you might want a couple of suits if you want to look more formal, or just a couple jackets if yo want to look more casual, either one might be more appropriate depending on the specific work you do
what is it that you work as?
dress shirts are a must if you're meeting people on the clock in a number of jobs, though again, depends on your job
sneakers and boat shoes are most likely going to be too casual no matter the job, look for any type of brown dress shoe if you want to look formal or moccasin if you want to be on the casual side
>pic related
pic related is dressed for new years' eve 1999, to avoid looking like that you can, in order of importance:
not wear a black tie, especially with a black suit
not wear a white shirt, especially with a black suit
not wear a black suit
not wear a suit at all
